definition:
Suppose $A$ is an open set in $\mathbb{C}$ and
$f(z)=f(re^{i\theta})=u(r,\theta)+iv(r,\theta): A\subset\mathbb{C} \to \mathbb{C}$
is a function. If the derivative of $f(z)$ exists at
$z_0=(r_0,\theta_0)$. Then the functions $u$, $v$ at $z_0$ satisfy:
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial u}{\partial r} & = & \frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial v}{\partial \theta}\\
\frac{\partial v}{\partial r} & = & -\frac{1}{r}\frac{\partial u}{\partial \theta}\end{aligned}$$
which are called *Cauchy-Riemann equations* in polar form.\
\
